message_1:
Consider a dataset containing the following scores of 10 students in 4 subjects: 

| Student | Subject 1 | Subject 2 | Subject 3 | Subject 4 |
|---------|-----------|-----------|-----------|-----------|
| 1       | 60        | 75        | 50        | 80        |
| 2       | 80        | 85        | 90        | 95        |
| 3       | 70        | 60        | 75        | 80        |
| 4       | 50        | 40        | 30        | 20        |
| 5       | 60        | 80        | 70        | 75        |
| 6       | 90        | 85        | 80        | 75        |
| 7       | 70        | 60        | 50        | 40        |
| 8       | 90        | 95        | 85        | 80        |
| 9       | 50        | 30        | 40        | 20        |
| 10      | 85        | 90        | 80        | 75        |

Using Principal Component Analysis (PCA), find the first two principal components and their corresponding eigenvalues.
message_2:
To find the first two principal components and their corresponding eigenvalues using PCA, follow these steps:

1. Standardize the dataset
2. Calculate the covariance matrix
3. Calculate the eigenvectors and eigenvalues of the covariance matrix
4. Sort the eigenvectors by their corresponding eigenvalues in descending order
5. Select the first two eigenvectors (principal components) and their corresponding eigenvalues

Step 1: Standardize the dataset

| Student | Subject 1 | Subject 2 | Subject 3 | Subject 4 |
|---------|-----------|-----------|-----------|-----------|
| 1       | -0.707    | 0.392     | -1.162    | 0.707     |
| 2       | 0.707     | 0.980     | 1.162     | 1.414     |
| 3       | 0         | -0.196    | 0.291     | 0.707     |
| 4       | -1.414    | -1.176    | -1.743    | -1.414    |
| 5       | -0.707    | 0.588     | 0         | 0.354     |
| 6       | 1.414     | 0.980     | 0.582     | 0.354     |
| 7       | 0         | -0.196    | -1.162    | -0.707    |
| 8       | 1.414     | 1.373     | 0.873     | 0.707     |
| 9       | -1.414    | -1.569    | -0.873    | -1.414    |
| 10      | 1.007     | 1.176     | 0.582     | 0.354     |

Step 2: Calculate the covariance matrix

|         | Subject 1 | Subject 2 | Subject 3 | Subject 4 |
|---------|-----------|-----------|-----------|-----------|
| Subj 1  | 1.111     | 0.850     | 0.721     | 0.721     |
| Subj 2  | 0.850     | 1.111     | 0.721     | 0.850     |
| Subj 3  | 0.721     | 0.721     | 1.111     | 0.721     |
| Subj 4  | 0.721     | 0.850     | 0.721     | 1.111     |

Step 3: Calculate the eigenvectors and eigenvalues of the covariance matrix

Eigenvalues: λ1 = 3.526, λ2 = 0.791, λ3 = 0.126, λ4 = 0.000
Eigenvectors:
v1 = [0.500, 0.500, 0.500, 0.500]
v2 = [-0.500, -0.500, 0.500, 0.500]
v3 = [0.707, -0.707, 0.000, 0.000]
v4 = [0.000, 0.000, -0.707, 0.707]

Step 4: Sort the eigenvectors by their corresponding eigenvalues in descending order

λ1 = 3.526, v1 = [0.500, 0.500, 0.500, 0.500]
